title: RS22581
content: The Securities Act of 1933 requires securities to be registered with the SEC before being offered to the public. The registration statement includes a prospectus for purchasers and Part II for inspection. Schedule A and Section 10(a) outline the required information for the registration statement and prospectus. Regulations issued by the commission provide additional guidance. The Securities Act of 1933 mandates registration of securities with the SEC before public offering. Regulations detail the registration process, exemptions, and types of securities. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 focuses on disclosure to investors through periodic reports. Issuers meeting specific criteria must register under the 1934 Act and file reports with the SEC. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires companies to file detailed reports with the SEC, including annual and quarterly reports with all material information for investors. Failure to disclose material information can lead to legal action under various sections of the Act, such as Section 18(a) and Section 10(b). Regulations specify the information these reports must provide, and exemptions are available. The Investment Company Act of 1940 mandates registration with the SEC for investment companies, restricting activities involving securities and affiliations of directors. Registered investment companies must file reports and financial statements. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 defines an investment adviser as one who advises on securities value or investment decisions for compensation. The Insider Trading Sanctions Act of 1984 increases sanctions against insider trading to deter violations. Insider trading involves trading securities with material nonpublic information. The SEC requires investment advisers to register and prohibits the use of interstate commerce without registration. The Insider Trading and Securities Fraud Enforcement Act of 1988 expanded civil penalties for insider trading, increased jail terms and fines for securities law violations, initiated a bounty program for informants, and required firms to prevent misuse of inside information. The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 aimed to reduce frivolous shareholder lawsuits. The Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998 (SLUSA) was enacted to limit shareholder lawsuits in federal courts by appointing a lead plaintiff, ensuring full disclosure of settlement terms, providing a safe harbor for forward-looking statements, and requiring auditor disclosure of corporate fraud. It was a response to perceived shortcomings of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (PSLRA) in curbing fraudulent practices in corporations. The Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998 (SLUSA) aimed to limit shareholder lawsuits in federal courts by establishing criteria for bringing securities fraud cases. It addressed perceived failures of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (PSLRA) and required securities fraud cases to be brought only in federal courts under specific conditions. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 was prompted by corporate scandals like Enron and WorldCom, leading to renewed interest in enacting stricter corporate regulations. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, enacted in response to corporate scandals, established stricter corporate responsibility legislation. It created the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, restricted accounting firms from providing certain services, and required additional disclosures for public companies. Dodd-Frank, passed after the financial downturn, made significant changes to financial regulation, affecting the securities industry in various ways. Dodd-Frank Act impacts the securities industry by regulating over-the-counter swaps markets, creating new powers for the SEC, and increasing investor protection measures. It establishes an Office of the Investor Advocate, whistleblower bounty program, and requirements for executive compensation disclosure and proxy solicitation materials. Dodd-Frank also mandates the oversight of public accounting firms through the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. The STOCK Act amends various titles of the U.S. Code to prohibit insider trading by Members of Congress and employees. The JOBS Act aims to ease securities reporting requirements to encourage funding for small businesses and startups. A growth company, with annual gross revenues less than $1 billion, can phase in SEC regulations and submit a draft registration statement confidentially. Title III exempts certain companies from the 1933 Securities Act's registration requirements if specific conditions are met, such as limits on securities sold and using a funding portal for transactions.
